message:
Ok , this post re the latest Twitter leaks we discussed earlier.

I was discussing the same thing with someone who believes that its not a malware , its a leak from inside twitter "The guy is the CTO  of a security Agency which serves CNN, BBC and some big cats so."

i got so many surprising info from him "which im not sure 100% is correct"

1- As i said he believes its not a malware  
2- Twitter uses SHA-1 and many others "which is easy to recovery , i think couple of minutes should be enough".

So what i think -or need to discuss- is that 
1- how come all of those does not use a 2nd factor and risk context assessment too !
2- HSBC uses a simple  but nice method , they doesn't store passwords in hashes instead i think its just encrypted, then they ask you for a random combination of your password not the full one like "1st 3rd and last digits only" , which prevents all kind of malware , MITM  , however still raise high risk for insiders attacks.
3- (EDIT) if we got 36 million hashed password we will need about 70 Years to recover it , however this might happen in a distributed system.

Any thoughts from our Security giants here ?

data.message:
i still think it is far fetched to say this breach is from twitter internal system, if someone can read twitter internal database there are some more profitable things to do than sell the passwords

Twitter does not use SHA-1 to hash passwords , they use bcryt 
source: https://twitter.com/_mwc/status/740764470708965376

your source is mistaken hashing passwords for serving certificates which they do use SHA-1 for 

i still need more proof to even consider the possibility this was not done by malware 

and i think your HSBC example is wrong or misunderstood or at least i hope so, hashing is way better than encryption in case of password storing because in encryption the key have to be stored somewhere but in hashing there is no key
